content.description:
Sit start, on a jug right hand, and a left handed pinch on a cobble. The crux is short, and provides a choice of slopes, crimps, and pinches to use. Which ever holds used, youll then throw big and left to a granite jug, then top out straight up.

This climb is way easier if you're tall, You'll be able to use a toe hook throughout the crux moves.
content.location: In the boulders across the creek. In a small corridor like area.

content.description:
Pronounced "StOn", Wonderful movement on perfectly sculptured holds, just a tad short. Established by Joe Chun, and named after the strongest man, Steve Han.

Start as low as  possible on holds that I can't remember.
content.location: This little arete bolder is located in the main area, maybe 20 feet away from the perplexity boulder and the obligatory boulder.

content.description:
"Sex on the Beach" climbs up a concave shaped wall on the absolute most solid conglomerate rock on the planet. There are practically no holds on this climb, but just enough to make it to the top. Despite the grade being lower, it gives many quite the challenge.

Start standing with a left hand on a two finger shark tooth side pull, and a right hand on the on a slopey sidepull. The beginning is the most difficult. Bringing a right foot up next to your right and, and then bumping your right hand up into a sidepull/ undercling section. Then go up to the small holds on the lip and top that shit out.
content.location: The Sex on the beach boulder is located on the other side of the creek, in the across the creek boulders. After finding a way across the creek, (water is always changing things) there is an obvious cluster of boulders. Sex on the beach is located more down the creek, and is in a small corridor between two boulders. The climb cant be seen unless you're right next to it. If you stand on top of the tallest block in the across the creek area, you'll be able to see the sex on the beach boulder right behind it.

content.description: You start on the far left side of the boulder and traverse right on a series of crimps and side pulls till a couple huge underlings, find away over the final hump onto the final slab of the climb and then take it to the top. As very safe, and amazing problem.You can start on the underlings for a short, yet direct fun warm up.
content.location: In the most central area of the conglomerate boulders, on the boulder right next to perplexity. The boulder is an eye catcher. Hard to miss it if following the creek down.

content.description:
Start on obvious holds,(I don't actually remember what they look like) and climb straight up. A seriously fun problem. Not really good for pads,

I've had better descriptions.
content.protection: maybe one small pad, not the best landing. tree trunk is sort of in the way.
content.location: Across the creek boulders, Up stream from  twenty yards from "Super Fly Me". Its the more western face of the boulder. There are almost two different ground levels for this face, "Saint Nicholas" is on the upper level part slightl more upstream. The right side and slightly taller face is the climb "sweaty nips".

content.description: starts with your hand crossed low to the left, still standing though. then pull up using small crimps and feet to finesse your way to the top. You can bail out of this climb left or right, and take an easier less steep route to the top, which go at v1. For full value go straight up the steepest part using a seam over the lip to pull yourself over.
content.location: Located in the main warm up area. Very obvious water polished boulder. one the tallest in the area. Its the middle line straight up the steepest and tallest part of the boulder.

content.description: Start on the holds that you're going to want to start with. In the center of the boulder is a blackish right handed slopey crimp, and a left handed hold that's the same type of rock but it is an under cling/ side pull. Climb directly up the face but exit slightly early to the left. IF  you're there, you'll want to hit this climb. (If you use the left arête, its a fun variation we call "Conpression", which is a bit more difficult. top out in the same place.)
content.protection: good landing, one pad is fine if any
content.location: Adjacent to the "Perplexity Boulder", same face and boulder as the traverse line "serendipity". The most center direct line.

content.description:
"The Monument" is Piru creeks most difficult climb so far, on some of the most solid rock around. Its a sit start inside the small cave of the boulder. Start crossed on two crimps right next to each other, and then traverse right around the boulder starting until on the complete other side, where you're on a thin slab face, and have to make a big move to the lip. From start to finnish this climb is brutal. Crux is probably falling into the arête before the slab.

Still unrepeated, someone should come try it
content.location: In the Main area of the Conglomerate boulders. Right next to "heel huckin" and the long over hung boulder.

content.description: Located in the main area of piru creek, next to all of the warm ups. The Hum of the stone boulder is adjacent to the Obligatory boulder as well as the "perplexity boulder". The line follows the obvious sloping arête from low and left, up and right. The entire line is difficult involving techy footwork with slopes and crimps. Good boulder for a lowball. Incredible rock quality. A low start has still yet to be done, would add a few hard moves. For the original line, do a hard rock over mantle press, and exit before hitting the  holds used for "easy arête" the short arête on the right side of the boulder.

Sit start in an uncomfortable nook under the seat looking part of the boulder. Hands start on a rail/crimp above. Throw a heel hook and wrestle until you mantle. Climb is done when you're sitting on the throne.
content.protection: None needed. It's the lowest of lowballs.
content.location: A few hundred feet before the chute. Pretty obvious seat-looking boulder made of sandstone.

content.description: Starts on The left side of the face, on a massive foot ledge, climb up obvious features and pinches to a big move to a blind pocket on a small ledge. Then get high feet and bump up the arête to the lip! Tallest boulder problem in the conglomerate area. P.s. the crux is the throw to the pocket, which is about 2/3rds way up the problem. Still unrepeated.
content.protection: A pad party would be wise.
content.location: There are two huge boulders with massive faces in the conglomerate area, the one farther down stream is the money. Its located right before the main area of the conglomerate boulders, where Perplexity, Obligatory, Serendipity, and The Monument. On the steep face of the Commit or Quit boulder, facing the creek is a massive  steep, partially hover hung face. Starts on the left side on obvious holds and goes straight up.

content.description: A super interesting little problem which is all about body positioning. It starts on an obvious left hand full pad crimp, and a right hand on a slopey orange side pull cobble. grab the thin crimp on the face with your left hand, then pull up to better sidepulls with the right hand. Tricky, until you find the right body positioning.
content.protection: ground under your feet. its ultra lowball (Due to storms over the past few years, its no longer ultra lowball!)
content.location: On the "Perplexity" boulder. far right side, basically up the slopey arête.

content.description: Start on a crimpy rail, and climb straight up the short buldge. Was Lowball, not so much anymore, decent warm up. Great rock quality.
content.location: Perplexity boulder, In between "Perplexity" and "Body Language"

content.description: The climb starts on two obvious holds, left and on a good white granite 3 finger full pad mini jug, and the right hand is on a slopey divot. With a high left foot you lock off and throw with your left hand to a crimp rail. Match the crimp rail and move up the face using a good obvious under cling and another obvious crimp. Pull the last moves using potential side pulls, a slopey rail, or a crimp to get to the top. *note, the true line goes straight up the face with the arête off. With the arête on the upper section of the climb will be a bit easier, especially if you're short.
content.location: Absent Minded is on the vertical face, facing the creek, of the first larger boulder after doing the class four scramble at the end of the approach. Once you shimmy down the small shoot on the approach walk about 20 yards down stream following the trail and The "Absent Minded" boulder should be in sight. There are two Huge over hung faces (25 feet) on separate boulders in the main area. If you hit either one you've gone to far. From the first Huge over hung boulder, you can see "Absent Minded".
